fields.description:
Some of the tests in containermanager.linux.runtime failed in Windows due to 

*Error Message*
 *'posix:permissions' not supported as initial attribute*

We use PosixFilePermission which can be used only with operating systems which are compatibile with POSIX:

A file attribute view that provides a view of the file attributes commonly associated with files on file systems used by operating systems that implement the Portable Operating System Interface (POSIX) family of standards.Operating systems that implement the POSIX family of standards commonly use file systems that have a file owner, group-owner, and related access permissions. Windows unfortunatelly doesn't support POSIX file systems so this is why your code doesn't work.
fields.summary: Exclude containermanager.linux test classes on Windows

comments.body: cc. [~gphillips] , [~rkanter], [~elgoiri], [~jlowe]
The java package is containermanager.*linux*.runtime, so is it reasonable to put something like {{assume(!isWindows)}} in the tests, or are some of the affected tests expected to work on Windows?

Thanks [~jlowe] , I have the same doubt and I want to group them. Let's start from \{{TestJavaSandboxLinuxContainerRuntime}} and \{{JavaSandboxLinuxContainerRuntime}} added in YARN-5280. [~gphillips] , I suppose this test should not run in Windows. Can you confirm?

I'm fine with using {{PlatformAssumptions.assumeNotWindows()}}.
I'd like to fix this in 2.9 too but this was introduced in HADOOP-9427.
Can you provide a different patch for branch-2?
[~giovanni.fumarola] - That is correct, TestJavaSandboxLinuxContainerRuntime should not run in windows.

Since this part of the source tree is specific to the Linux runtime, would it make more sense to update the pom to exclude this directory tree from tests when running on Windows?  That would be a lot simpler than tacking assumeNotWindows() on every one of the tests (and remembering to do that for future tests in this part of the source tree).

bq. would it make more sense to update the pom to exclude this directory tree from tests when running on Windows? 

I'm not familiar with that approach.
Is there any example for that?

Attaching a patch that I _think_ does what I proposed.  It adds a native-win profile to the hadoop-yarn-server-nodemanager project pom that activates when building on Windows and excludes tests that have a package prefix of org.apache.hadoop.yarn.server.nodemanager.containermanager.linux.

Thanks [~jlowe] for the patch.
Is this used somewhere else?

[~giovanni.fumarola] can you test on Windows?
Yetus should be able to tell us if Linux still runs it.

bq. Is this used somewhere else?

Using the pom to exclude a chunk of tests is currently being done by hadoop-kms, hadoop-hdfs-https, hadoop-azure (for failsafe vs. surefire but similar concept), hadoop-yarn-server-nodemanager, and hadoop-yarn-registry.

Thanks [~jlowe].
+1 on  [^YARN-8359.001.patch].
We should change the title of the JIRA as it does not disable only the runtime but the whole {{org.apache.hadoop.yarn.server.nodemanager.containermanager.linux}}.

For the record, the [current Windows daily|https://builds.apache.org/job/hadoop-trunk-win/481/testReport/] build has almost 30 errors caused by this class.

I would like to get a Yetus run though.
Re-upload?

I updated the JIRA summary.  As for the Yetus run, I only recently moved this to Patch Available.  I had uploaded the patch as a proof-of-concept, but it looks like we can use it directly.  So the QA bot should be coming along soon.

The unit test failure is unrelated.  I attached a new patch that fixes the tabs whitespace issue.

Thanks [~jlowe] for taking care of it.

+1 on v2.

The Yetus run for [^YARN-8359.001.patch] seems right.
[~giovanni.fumarola], did you confirm that this test now indeed gets ignored for Windows?

Yes, the entire block containermanager.linux is skipped.

The test execution goes from launcher to localizer.

Thanks [~giovanni.fumarola] for checking.
The {{TestContainerManager}} fails randomly on the second run of  [^YARN-8359.002.patch] but in any case, I think this is good to go.
[~jlowe], do you mind committing?

I went ahead and committed.
Thanks [~jlowe] for the patch and [~giovanni.fumarola] for the review.
Committed to trunk, branch-3.1, branch-3.0, branch-2, and branch-2.9.
